learning_outcomes.description: Understand and reflect critically on ancient and modern approaches to art, beauty and aesthetic experience
Understand and analyse arguments, concepts and problems in aesthetics
Understand better the complex nature of philosophical texts in the tradition of aesthetics
Demonstrate reasoned thought, creativity, and a high quality of written expression
Examine, discuss and debate the main issues regarding the relevance of aesthetic theories to our contemporary context

assessments.due_date:
Week 7, Wed 2:00 pm

Marking criteria and rubrics are available in the 'Assessment' folder in Blackboard for this course.
assessments.task_description:
Topic: Write a 1500 word essay on class material covered in weeks 2-6. Topics and detailed instructions will be provided on the course Blackboard site in the assessment folder. 

Referencing Style: Refer to task sheet.

Word Limits: A word count that is within +/- 10% of the set length (word limit) is acceptable. Word count does not include footnotes, however, discursive footnotes are included in the world count. A word count that is outside these 10% will receive a proportionate penalty and will be graded against the grading criteria.

AI: This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Please submit your essay to turnitin by 2PM on the due date. Submission guidelines will be provided on the task sheet on the course blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Students are required to participate actively in a community of enquiry in tutorials and complete in-class exercises designed to test comprehension of the required reading. Students with an accommodation must contact the course coordinator to arrange an alternative. Marks out of 15% will be awarded in weeks 7 and 13.

You will be expected to:

  • Read the required reading prior to attending the tutorial
  • Actively participate in class discussions.
  • Prepare a question on the reading.
  • Complete an activity consisting of a mix of multiple choice questions and/or short answer questions and/or reflections on a stimulus in class.


Each tutorial is worth 3% (1% for active participation, and 2% for the in-class exercise).

More detailed instructions will be provided on the course blackboard site, including information about make-up opportunities for missed tutorials.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Lecture series

A series of lectures addressing key figures and topics in philosophical aesthetics. The aim of these lectures is to introduce students to ancient and modern approaches to art, beauty and aesthetic experience, as well as to some critical perspectives on these approaches. Material presented in lectures will form the basis for further discussion and analysis in tutorials and assessment tasks.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1: What is Philosophical Aesthetics?

General introduction to the course with an explanation of what philosophical aesthetics is, what issues it raises, and the figures we will discuss.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1: What is Philosophical Aesthetics? General introduction to the course with an explanation of what philosophical aesthetics is, what issues it raises, and the figures we will discuss.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 12(02 Mar - 24 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial Discussion

Group discussion of set weekly readings. Tutorials start in week 2.
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial Discussion Group discussion of set weekly readings. Tutorials start in week 2.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Plato's Theory of Art

A discussion of Plato's theory of art as 'imitation of appearance', and the psychological theory that underpins Plato's normative assessment of art's value to life.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: Plato's Theory of Art A discussion of Plato's theory of art as 'imitation of appearance', and the psychological theory that underpins Plato's normative assessment of art's value to life.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: Plato on Art and Politics

A discussion of the role of art in Plato's ideal Republic.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: Plato on Art and Politics A discussion of the role of art in Plato's ideal Republic.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: Kant's subjectivist Aesthetics

A discussion of Kant's project in aesthetics and its historical background; namely 18th century aesthetic theories before Kant. We consider how Kant's aesthetic theory represents a resolution to a conflict between prior objectivist and subjectivist aesthetic theories.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4: Kant's subjectivist Aesthetics A discussion of Kant's project in aesthetics and its historical background; namely 18th century aesthetic theories before Kant. We consider how Kant's aesthetic theory represents a resolution to a conflict between prior objectivist and subjectivist aesthetic theories.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5: Kant's subjectivist Aesthetics II

A discussion of Kant's account of aesthetic judgment and its background in his epistemology. We consider how aesthetic judgments differ from other kinds of judgments and what follows from this difference, and we reflect on the significance of aesthetic experience in human life in Kant's terms, and raise critical questions about Kant's project in aesthetics.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5: Kant's subjectivist Aesthetics II A discussion of Kant's account of aesthetic judgment and its background in his epistemology. We consider how aesthetic judgments differ from other kinds of judgments and what follows from this difference, and we reflect on the significance of aesthetic experience in human life in Kant's terms, and raise critical questions about Kant's project in aesthetics.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6: The Kantian Sublime

A discussion of Kant's account of fine art and genius, the moral and political significance of the distinction he draws between the beautiful and the Sublime, and the broader moral and political issues raised by the Kantian sublime.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 6: The Kantian Sublime A discussion of Kant's account of fine art and genius, the moral and political significance of the distinction he draws between the beautiful and the Sublime, and the broader moral and political issues raised by the Kantian sublime.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7: Schiller and Romanticism

A discussion of Schiller's critical response to Kantian aesthetic theory, his theory of art as a form of education and an expression of the "play drive", and his account of aesthetics as redemption from alienation.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 7: Schiller and Romanticism A discussion of Schiller's critical response to Kantian aesthetic theory, his theory of art as a form of education and an expression of the "play drive", and his account of aesthetics as redemption from alienation.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8: Hegel's "objectivist" Aesthetics

A discussion of Hegelﾒs critical response to Kantian aesthetics, and an introduction to his alternative 'objectivist' aesthetic theory. Themes covered include the relation between art and truth; the relation between form and content in works of art; and the significance of Hegel's account of the historical development of the arts. We also discuss Hegel's infamous end of art thesis.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 8: Hegel's "objectivist" Aesthetics A discussion of Hegelﾒs critical response to Kantian aesthetics, and an introduction to his alternative 'objectivist' aesthetic theory. Themes covered include the relation between art and truth; the relation between form and content in works of art; and the significance of Hegel's account of the historical development of the arts. We also discuss Hegel's infamous end of art thesis.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9: Nietzsche on Nihilism and Art

A discussion of Nietzsche's aesthetics as it is presented in The Birth of Tragedy. Themes to be discussed include Nietzsche's understanding of tragedy as way of combating nihilism and existential dread, the relation between art and truth, and the role of art in cultural renewal.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 9: Nietzsche on Nihilism and Art A discussion of Nietzsche's aesthetics as it is presented in The Birth of Tragedy . Themes to be discussed include Nietzsche's understanding of tragedy as way of combating nihilism and existential dread, the relation between art and truth, and the role of art in cultural renewal.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 10: Heidegger on Art and Technology

A discussion of Heidegger's reflections on the relation between art, technology and politics, and his critique of aesthetic theory.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 10: Heidegger on Art and Technology A discussion of Heidegger's reflections on the relation between art, technology and politics, and his critique of aesthetic theory.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11: Adorno on the Culture Industry

A discussion of Adorno and Horkheimer's seminal 'culture industry' essay. Topics covered include capitalism, the commodification of art, and the ideological function of the art in the 'culture industry'.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 11: Adorno on the Culture Industry A discussion of Adorno and Horkheimer's seminal 'culture industry' essay. Topics covered include capitalism, the commodification of art, and the ideological function of the art in the 'culture industry'.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12 Benjamin on Art, Aura, and Technology

A discussion of Benjamin's thesis concerning the impact of techniques of 'mechanical reproduction' on the "aura" of the work of art. Topics to be discussed include the significance and cultural impact of the loss of the aura and its effects on art's reception, and the revolutionary potential of film as a vehicle for democratic expression.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 13: Review

A critical review of the European aesthetic tradition drawing on feminist and postcolonial critiques.
